Award.AwardTitle: TTP: Medium: Democratizing Secure Password Management

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The theft of passwords and other user credentials from online services has become an epidemic, with password breaches regularly impacting large user populations and leaving both consumers and businesses vulnerable to attack. A number of research results point the way toward methods that could greatly improve the security of password systems. There is thus both an urgent need and a clear opportunity to transform the general state of industry practice in password management. Toward this end, the researchers build an easy-to-deploy password-protection system called PASS. PASS incorporates recent research on state-of-the-art methods to protect passwords and related user credentials into new innovations. PASS aims to make available to even the smallest organizations a complete, principled, server-side password protection system that offers far stronger security by default than any known existing system.

PASS transitions later stage research into practice and develops novel extensions to several of the PIs' recent research innovations, including: (1) Pythia, a service for password hardening. Password hardening is technique that applies a cryptographic transform to stored and user-submitted passwords to render them hard to crack. Pythia incorporates a novel and practical such cryptographic transformation, known as a verifiable partially-oblivious pseudorandom function. This transform not only hardens passwords, but also protects against compromise of the service that applies the cryptographic transform and makes it easy to update stored password data, thereby minimizing the impact of a breach. (2) Honey objects: A well established method for mitigating the damage caused by a breach is to incorporate fake or decoy data or services into a system. These objects, often called 'honey objects', serve to divert or deceive an adversary. PASS will incorporate honey objects such as fake user and administrative accounts, doing so in a way that builds on the PIs' recent research into principled use of such objects. (3) Typo-tolerance: In support of an emerging industry practice that enhances usability for clients, PASS will support the optional acceptance of passwords with certain common typographical errors. PASS will enable deployers to avoid current ad hoc methods for such typo-tolerance and instead leverage recent and ongoing research results to achieve a principled security / usability tradeoff. By offering these novel tools in a mature, modular development ecosystem for engineers and researchers, PASS serves not only as a platform to democratize advances in password-protection technologies but also as a stimulus and proving ground for new, practice-oriented research in the security community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Password theft and other security breaches continue to plague organizations large and small across a variety of systems. Even state-of-the-art techniques leave organizations vulnerable to a variety of security events affecting the confidentiality and integrity of digital assets. Additionally, existing security tools and techniques fail to offer important forms of flexibility that can make adoption and good security practices easier.

The goal of this project was to build tools for essential security goals, including password protection and blockchain system integrity, that are easy to deploy and that integrate recent research to achieve advanced forms of system hardening, security-event recovery, and usability. Our designs are intended to facilitate technology transfer to even small organizations by supporting complete, principled, server-side systems with security by default that exceed standards of even large sophisticated organizations.

Our work has yielded a number of notable transition-to-practice successes. Among them are:

  • User authentication technology: Our technology transfer efforts around key management, one of the seminal projects associated with this grant, have transitioned to OSO (https://www.osohq.com/), a Cornell Tech Runway Postdoctoral experience spinoff that has successfully raised $2.5 million in VC funding. 

  • Privacy-preserving oracle technology: We recently developed a system called DECO that enables high-assurance, privacy-preserving export of data from TLS-enabled web servers. One of its applications is to blockchain oracles. The technology was acquired from Cornell University by a blockchain company.

  • Decentralized identity: Building on DECO (as well as earlier, industry-licensed, NSF-funded technology called Town Crier), we have built a system called CanDID that we believe addresses a number of the key technical obstacles in decentralized identity. We are giving talks in a number of industry forums by request and collaborating with an industry partner on the development of a pilot system. We believe that our success with DECO in the course of this grant will serve as a springboard for additional transition-to-practice successes.

  • Privacy-preserving smart contracts: We developed a smart-contract system called Ekiden that leverages trusted hardware to achieve confidential, high-performance execution. We publicly released code for a preliminary version. Ekiden is the basis of one of the core technologies of a blockchain startup. 

  • Cornell information security collaboration: We have initiated a long-term collaboration with the Cornell Information Security Office (CISO), which handles IT security for the Cornell campus. By partnering with them we are aiming to continue our successes under this grant by creating a sustainable pipeline for tech transfer opportunities, as well as developing a research testbed that can leverage a large-scale production authentication system. (Cornell University has about 200,000 active accounts.) 

The research conducted under this grant has additionally provided training and professional development opportunities for a number of PhD students (and some undergraduates), who have been involved in translation of their research into artifacts with practical impact. These PhD students have gained a new perspective on and deepening of their practical understanding of their research, as well as opportunities to disseminate their research results to a wider community. Their successes have translated into both top-tier publications and industry impact.
